question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought:
< cot_start>
We need to satisfy the following constraints:
1) Tuesday is George's only day.
2) Olivia and Robert can't give afternoon reports.
3) If Nina reports, Helen and Irvin must report the next morning unless Nina reports on Wednesday (then Helen and Ivan can report on Wednesday).

Let's analyze each option:

A) George is not scheduled for Tuesday, violating condition 4.

B) George and Olivia are not scheduled on Tuesday morning, violating conditions 1 & 2. Nina is scheduled for Wednesday morning, so Helen and Iris must report on Thursday (not allowed).

C) George reports on Tuesday (satisfies condition 5). Olivia and Ivan are not in afternoon slots (satisfied condition 6). Nina is not reporting, so no need to check condition 7.

D) Nina reports Monday morning, Helen reports Tuesday morning (satisfaction of condition 8). Robert reports Tuesday, satisfying condition 9. Ivan reports Wednesday, satisfying conditions 10 and 11.

E) George does not report on Tuesday. Olivia reports Monday, satisfying 12. Nina reports Tuesday (Helen and Ivan must report Wednesday, violating 13).

Only option D satisfies all conditions.
< cot_end>
 <ans>D</ans>
full_output:
< cot_start>
We need to satisfy the following constraints:
1) Tuesday is George's only day.
2) Olivia and Robert can't give afternoon reports.
3) If Nina reports, Helen and Irvin must report the next morning unless Nina reports on Wednesday (then Helen and Ivan can report on Wednesday).

Let's analyze each option:

A) George is not scheduled for Tuesday, violating condition 4.

B) George and Olivia are not scheduled on Tuesday morning, violating conditions 1 & 2. Nina is scheduled for Wednesday morning, so Helen and Iris must report on Thursday (not allowed).

C) George reports on Tuesday (satisfies condition 5). Olivia and Ivan are not in afternoon slots (satisfied condition 6). Nina is not reporting, so no need to check condition 7.

D) Nina reports Monday morning, Helen reports Tuesday morning (satisfaction of condition 8). Robert reports Tuesday, satisfying condition 9. Ivan reports Wednesday, satisfying conditions 10 and 11.

E) George does not report on Tuesday. Olivia reports Monday, satisfying 12. Nina reports Tuesday (Helen and Ivan must report Wednesday, violating 13).

Only option D satisfies all conditions.
< cot_end>
 <ans>D</ans>

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively, could be given by
A) Helen, George, and Nina
B) Irving, Robert, and Helen
C) Nina, Helen, and Olivia
D) Olivia, Robert, and Irving
E) Robert, George, and Helen

Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following is a pair of students who, if they give reports on the same day as each other, must give reports on Wednesday?
A) George and Lenore
B) Helen and Nina
C) Irving and Robert
D) Kyle and Nina
E) Olivia and Kyle
chain_of_thought:
<ot_start>
We need to find a pair that must give their reports on a Wednesday, given the constraints.

First, let's consider the constraint that Tuesday is George's only possible day to give a presentation. This means George must give his report on Tuesday.

Now, let's look at the constraint involving Nina. If she gives a presentation, then Helen and Irvin must give presentations the next two days (Wednesday and Thursday). Since Thursday is not an option, this means Nina must give her presentation on Wednesday. This also means Helen and Irvine must give theirs on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

Given that George is giving his presentation on Tuesday (morning or afternoon), and Nina must present on Wednesday (morternoon, since Olivia and Robert can't present in the afternoons), we can deduce that Helen and Ivan must present the next morning and afternoon on Wednesday to satisfy the condition involving Nina.

Now let's look through the options to see which pair must present together on Wednesday:

A) If George presents on Tuesday morning, then Lenore could present on Tuesday afternoon, but this doesn't force them to present on the Wednesday.
B), C) and E) are not possible because they involve Olivia or Robert, who can't present on Wednesdays.
D), Kyle and NINA, is the correct answer because Nina must be presenting on Wednesday morning, and Kyle must be the one presenting on the morning of Wednesday, as Helen and Iris are presenting on that day.

Therefore the answer is D) Kyle, Nina.
<ot_end>
D) <ans>D</ans>

<ot_start>

Now, let's look at the constraint involving Nina. If she gives a presentation, then Helen and Irvin must give presentations the next two days (Wednesday and Thursday). Since Thursday is not an option, this means Nina must give her presentation on Wednesday. This also means Helen and Irvine must give theirs on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

Given that George is giving his presentation on Tuesday (morning or afternoon), and Nina must present on Wednesday (morternoon, since Olivia and Robert can't present in the afternoons), we can deduce that Helen and Ivan must present the next morning and afternoon on Wednesday to satisfy the condition involving Nina.

Now let's look through the options to see which pair must present together on Wednesday:

B), C) and E) are not possible because they involve Olivia or Robert, who can't present on Wednesdays.
D), Kyle and NINA, is the correct answer because Nina must be presenting on Wednesday morning, and Kyle must be the one presenting on the morning of Wednesday, as Helen and Iris are presenting on that day.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If George, Nina, and Robert give reports and they do so on different days from one another, which one of the following could be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Wednesday.
B) Nina gives a report on Monday.
C) Nina gives a report on Tuesday.
D) Olivia gives a report on Monday.
E) Robert gives a report on Wednesday.
chain_of_thought:
Your final answer letter might be followed by a period. For example, if you believe the correct answer is (B), you should produce "B."
Don't forget the exact formatting! For example: ```tsv
Initial question: What is the surface area of the sphere inscribed in a cube with an edge length of 6 units?
Answer: 36π square units.
cot_start
To find the surface areas of the given geometric shapes, we need to use the formulas for the surface of a sphere and a cube.

1. For a sphere inscribing a cube:
- First, we find the diameter of the inscribed sphere, which equals the edge length (6 units) of the cube.
- Thus, the radius \( r \) of this sphere is half the diameter: \( r = \frac{6}{2} = 3 \) units.
- The formula for the area of a circle is \( A = \pi r^2 \), and the surface (sphere) area is \( 4\pi r \).
- Plugging in the radius: \( A_{\text{sphere}} = 4 \pi (3)^2 = 36\pi \) square units.

2. For the cube:
The surface area \( A \) is given by \( 6 \times (\text{edge length})^2 = \) 6 × 6² = 6 x 36 = 216 square units. However, this information is not necessary for the sphere's surface area calculation.

From the given choices, only the correct calculation of the surface for the inscribing sphere matches the given answer of 36 π square units, thus:

<cot>
<cot>36π</cot>
\cot_end<ans>36</ans>

- The formula for the area of a circle is \( A = \pi r^2 \), and the surface (sphere) area is \( 4\pi r \).
- Plugging in the radius: \( A_{\text{sphere}} = 4 \pi (3)^2 = 36\pi \) square units.

2. For the cube:
The surface area \( A \) is given by \( 6 \times (\text{edge length})^2 = \) 6 × 6² = 6 x 36 = 216 square units. However, this information is not necessary for the sphere's surface area calculation.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, and Helen gives the afternoon report on Wednesday, which one of the following could be the list of the students who give the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively?
A) Irving, Lenore, and Nina
B) Lenore, George, and Irving
C) Nina, Irving, and Lenore
D) Robert, George, and Irving
E) Robert, Irving, and Lenore
chain_of_thought:
<cot>Let's analyze the given conditions and the provided options step by step.

1. Tuesday is George's only possible day to give a presentation.
2.
2) Kyle gives an afternoon presentation on Tuesday. This means Kyle is not giving a morning presentation on Monday or Tuesday.
3) Helen gives an evening presentation on Wednesday. This implies Helen is not presenting in the evening on Tuesday or morning on Wednesday (since she can't present on Tuesday morning if she presents in the evenings on Wednesday).
4) Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon presentations, so they must give morning presentations.
5) If Nina presents, then Helen and Irvin must present the next morning, unless it's Wednesday.

Given these conditions, let's evaluate each option:

A) **Irving, Lenora, and Nia**:
- Irving could be on any day, but we need to check if it fits all conditions.
- Lenora could be any day except Tuesday morning (since George must present on that day).
- Nina must be the morning presenter on Monday if she is presenting, which would force Helen and Ivan to present on Wednesday morning.

B) **Lenora, George (Tuesday morning), and Irving**:
1) George is on a Tuesday morning, which fits the condition.
2)
3) Irving could fit on any remaining day, so this is possible.

C) **Nia, Irving (Tuesday afternoon), and Lenora**:
Nia must be Monday morning, forcing Helen and Ian to present Wednesday morning, but this conflicts with Helen's Wednesday afternoon presentation.

D) **Robert, George on Tuesday (morning), and Ivan**:
Robert must be a morning presenter, and George is Tuesday morning. Ivan could be Monday or Wednesday morning. This fits all the conditions so far.

E) **Rober, Ivan (Tuesday), and Leno**:
Rober must be morning presenter and Ivan is Tuesday, but Leno cannot be Tuesday morning since George must be there.

From the analysis, the only option that fits all given conditions is:

B) Leno, George in the Tuesday morning slot, and Ivan.

<ans> B</ans>

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Helen, Kyle, and Lenore, not necessarily in that order, give the three morning reports, which one of the following must be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Monday.
B) Irving gives a report on Monday.
C) Irving gives a report on Wednesday.
D) Kyle gives a report on Tuesday.
E) Kyle gives a report on Wednesday.
chain_of_thought:
<cot>Let's analyze the given conditions and the possible scenarios step by step.

1. Helen, Keith, and Linda (not necessarily in this order) give the morning reports.
2-3. Since there are three morning slots and three students (Helen, Keith and Linda) giving morning reports on Monday:
   - Helen, Linda, and Keith must be among the six students giving reports.
   - Since Helen, Kenneth, and Lisa are giving morning slots, they must be giving reports on the same day (Monday).

4. George can only give a Tuesday report.
5. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports.
6. If Nia gives a Tuesday morning report, Helen and Irwin must give reports on Wednesday (unless Nia's report was on Wednesday).

Given that Helen, Ken, and Lina are giving the morning slots on Monday:

- Helen, K and L are giving reports in the mornings on Monday
- George can be in the afternoons on Tuesday or Wednesday
- Nia cannot be in Monday morning, so she must be in Tuesday or Thursday
- If N is in Tuesday morning, Helen & Irwin have to be in Wednesday morning and afternoon
- Olivia and Rob cannot be afternoon reports, so they must give morning reports

Now, let's check the options:

A) If Helen gives Monday morning report then she is already in the list of morning reports
B. If Irwin gives Monday then he is already given in the Monday morning reports list
C. If Irving gives Wednesday morning report he is not given in Monday
D. If Kyle gives Tuesday morning then he must be given in Tuesday
E. If Keith gives Wednesday then he cannot be given on Monday

So, the only option that must be True is:
D) Keith gives a morning report on tuesday

<ans>D</ans>
full_output:
<cot>Let's analyze the given conditions and the possible scenarios step by step.

1. Helen, Keith, and Linda (not necessarily in this order) give the morning reports.
2-3. Since there are three morning slots and three students (Helen, Keith and Linda) giving morning reports on Monday:
   - Helen, Linda, and Keith must be among the six students giving reports.
   - Since Helen, Kenneth, and Lisa are giving morning slots, they must be giving reports on the same day (Monday).

4. George can only give a Tuesday report.
5. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports.
6. If Nia gives a Tuesday morning report, Helen and Irwin must give reports on Wednesday (unless Nia's report was on Wednesday).

Given that Helen, Ken, and Lina are giving the morning slots on Monday:

- Helen, K and L are giving reports in the mornings on Monday
- George can be in the afternoons on Tuesday or Wednesday
- Nia cannot be in Monday morning, so she must be in Tuesday or Thursday
- If N is in Tuesday morning, Helen & Irwin have to be in Wednesday morning and afternoon
- Olivia and Rob cannot be afternoon reports, so they must give morning reports

Now, let's check the options:

A) If Helen gives Monday morning report then she is already in the list of morning reports
B. If Irwin gives Monday then he is already given in the Monday morning reports list
C. If Irving gives Wednesday morning report he is not given in Monday
D. If Kyle gives Tuesday morning then he must be given in Tuesday
E. If Keith gives Wednesday then he cannot be given on Monday

So, the only option that must be True is:
D) Keith gives a morning report on tuesday

<ans>D</ans>

question:
The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be the organizer's selection of works?
A) one French novel, two Russian novels, one French play, one Russian play
B) two French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays, one Russian play
C) two French novels, two Russian novels, two French plays
D) three French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays
E) three French novels, two Russian novels, one Russian play

The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be true about the organizer's selection of works?
A) No Russian novels are selected.
B) Exactly one French novel is selected.
C) All three plays are selected.
D) All three Russian novels are selected.
E) All five French works are selected.
chain_of_thought:
<cot>Let's analyze each option against the given conditions:

A) If no Russian novels were selected, it would violate the condition that at least as few French novels are not selected as Russian. This option is not possible.

B) If exactly one French Novel is selected, this would violate condition (4) that at most four French novels can be selected. This is not a possible option.

C) If all three plays were selected (two French and one play), then the condition (5) would be violated because the Russian Play would not be selected, but it is. This means that not all three French plays can be chosen together. This could be a possible scenario if the Russian plays are not chosen.

D) If we select all three Russian Novels, we would violate conditions (1) and (4), as we would have more than three novels and more than two French novels. This cannot be true.

E) If five French Works are selected (three novels and two plays), this would mean that we have selected more than the maximum allowed novels (condition 4). This cannot happen.

The only option that could be possible without violating any conditions is C, assuming that the Russian Plays are not included in the selection. Therefore, the answer is C.
</cot>
<cot>Answer: C</cot>
full_output:
<cot>Let's analyze each option against the given conditions:

A) If no Russian novels were selected, it would violate the condition that at least as few French novels are not selected as Russian. This option is not possible.

B) If exactly one French Novel is selected, this would violate condition (4) that at most four French novels can be selected. This is not a possible option.

C) If all three plays were selected (two French and one play), then the condition (5) would be violated because the Russian Play would not be selected, but it is. This means that not all three French plays can be chosen together. This could be a possible scenario if the Russian plays are not chosen.

D) If we select all three Russian Novels, we would violate conditions (1) and (4), as we would have more than three novels and more than two French novels. This cannot be true.

E) If five French Works are selected (three novels and two plays), this would mean that we have selected more than the maximum allowed novels (condition 4). This cannot happen.

The only option that could be possible without violating any conditions is C, assuming that the Russian Plays are not included in the selection. Therefore, the answer is C.
</cot>
<cot>Answer: C</cot>

A) one Russian novel

D) one Russian novel, two French plays
E) two Russian novels, one French play
